**7.5 PWMIN Interface**


The device implements two PWMIN inputs, a low priority (PWMIN_LP) and a high priority (PWMIN_HP) input. The PWMIN 
signals evaluation is used to implement prioritized fallback modes, which use pre-defined PWM pulse length and LED current 
data, and a direct PWM signal feed-through mode.
The following figure shows the PWMIN state diagram. State changes are driven by the PWMIN signal level and a detection of 
a valid PWM input signal. The PWM detection timing parameter can be configured.


Each PWMIN input (PWMIN_LP, PWMIN_HP) implements the following states:


•
 bus configuration usage


•
 when related PWMIN pin input level is static 0


•
 PWM direct mode


•
 when related PWMIN pin receives a valid PWM signal


•
 fallback configuration mode


•
 when related PWMIN pin input level is static 1

The following figures and tables describe the modes generated by the PWMIN Interface depending on the two PWMIN pin 
states and their influence to the PWM System and current sinks configuration data usage.
The mode signals are generate per LED channel. The device implements a 2 bit PWMIN usage configuration per LED channel, 
which allows to enable the usage of the PWMIN_LP and PWMIN_HP input signals per LED channel. Please see STANDALONE 
area PWMIN_ENABLE_x_x values description for details.


Received PWM signals will be considered to be valid when its period is:


•

Period length measurement starts at each edge of PWMIN input signal. There are independent length measurement units, 
one for the rising PWMIN signal edge, one for the falling PWMIN signal edge.

**7.6 Digital IOs**


The signal polarity of some device digital input pins can be configured using the IO_CONFIG value in STANDALONE area. 
These pins are: OE, PWMIN_LP and PWMIN_HP.
This allows connecting inverted control signals to the device, enable the device internal inversion, hence make the device 
behave as if controlled by non-inverted control signals.
The description in the following chapters refers to the internal signal states, which represent the "normal" control signal 
polarity.
OE, PWMIN_LP and PWMIN_HP show a pull-down behavior if inversion is disabled. The pull direction changes with the selec-
ted polarity, and for this changes to pull-up if the invert option is selected.


The figures (6-11, 6-13 and 6-12) show the pull-up and pull-down IO typical current behavior of the digital IOs. The internal 
pull resistor voltage is limited, so for voltages above this limit the load current saturates depending on the pull direction.

The timing figure below shows an example timing of the prescaler counter, the period counter and different pulse lengths 
shown as LED channels a, b and c. In this example the prescaler is configured with a value of 5, resulting in a prescaler divid-
ing factor of 6 system clock cycles. The period counter in this example is configured with a value of 4 which results in count-
ing from 0 to 3. The period counter is incremented every time the prescaler counter is reset to 0 when reaching it's configura-
tion value. The period counter itself is reset to 0 every time it reaches it's period configuration value minus one. This results 
in a PWM period length equal to the PWM_PERIOD configuration value, based on a prescaled increment clock. In the 
example timing below, the pulse starting time stamps are equal and correspond to the period counter re-start event time 
stamp. The channel a is configured to generate a 2 PWM cycle pulse, the channel b is configured to generate a 3 PWM cycle 
pulse and the channels c generates a 100% duty cycle pulse. A channel PWM pulse length configured to be longer than the 
PWM period will result in 100% duty cycle for this channel.

## 16 Channel Automotive LED Driver with Bus Interface 
** **
## E522.59 


PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


Each PWM pulse generation logic channel uses its own virtual PWM period and can be set up to generate a PWM signal with 
duty cycles from 0% up to 100%. The PWM pulse starting points of the 16 channels can be configured using the PWM_CON-
FIG value as follows:


•
 all PWM pulses start at the same time stamp


•
 adjacent PWM channel pulse starting point distance = 0


•
 all PWM pulse starting points are distributed equidistantly over the PWM period


•
 adjacent PWM channel pulse starting point distance = PWM period / 16

**7.7.1.4 Diagnosis**
For diagnosis, a minimum duty cycle length is required. If the duty cycle pulses are too short, no diagnosis is possible. If lower
pulse length is used, no open/short detection is possible, but beside that the device will work without issues. No error bits or 
similar will be set! The shown example duty cycle lengths are valid under the condition that equidistant distribution of PWM 
channel starting point over the PWM period is configured (PWM_CONFIG.timing = 1) and no channels are digitally combined 
or use the advanced power management using external resistors. For more details a minimum pulse length calculation excel 
document is available on request.

PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


**7.7.1.5 Device firmware execution constraints**
The following IC-internal PWM interrupt-driven functions will not be executed in every PWM cycle any more. The impact on 
application is negligible from Elmos point of view as the mentioned functions are processed latest after 10ms, well within all 
safety relevant reaction times.


Table 7.7.1.5-1: Impact on firmware functions with PWM frequency above 500Hz


**Function**
**Impact on application**


Update of resistor binning median filter
Brightness change related to a change of binning resistor 
value will be visible some ms later than usually.


Retry measurements in OPEN/SHORT status
RETRY measurements of an OPEN or SHORT LED will not be 
done in every PWM cycle. In case the OPEN or SHORT error 
heals out again, it takes some ms later to recover to OK 
status.


Gate state measurement and check in firmware
Not visible to the application. Internal safety mechanism 
checking if the outputs are ON resp. OFF at the expected 
points in time. In some PWM cycles, this check will be 
skipped, but still a continuous observation is maintained.

status.


Gate state measurement and check in firmware
Not visible to the application. Internal safety mechanism 
checking if the outputs are ON resp. OFF at the expected 
points in time. In some PWM cycles, this check will be 
skipped, but still a continuous observation is maintained.


**7.7.2 OE PWM Masking**


The OE pin can be used to mask PWM signals generated by the PWM system generator.
When the OE pin is inactive (low level in case of non-inverted OE usage), the PWM pulses of all LED channels in bus mode are 
suppressed, which sets the related LED channel driver stages to an off state. When the OE pin is active (high level in case of 
non-inverted OE usage), this mask is removed and PWM signals of LED channels in bus mode are fed from the PWM gener-
ator to the related LED driver stages.
There is an option (via STANDALONE.PWM_CONFIG value) to apply the same masking behavior also to LED channels in bus 
timeout mode.


The OE pin state does not influence the PWMIN direct PWM, which is directly fed to the configured LED driver stages, when a
valid PWM at the PWMIN pins was recognized. All LED channels in a fallback mode are not masked and the PWM system gen-
erator signals are fed to these LED channel driver stages and are not influenced by the OE pin state.

Each current sink is based on a DAC with selectable full scale range. The range can be selected per LED using the

The current sink gets current strength information and the PWM duty cycle from the digital part.

ted with the ISINK_CONFIG value bit fields.


The following figures show the relation between the current configuration value (digital set value) and the resulting LED cur-
rent. The LED current can saturate above the selected range maximum current value. Below the selected range minimum cur-
rent value the LED current behavior can be non-linear including a possible saturation of the driven LED current. For this 
reason it's not recommended to select an LED current outside the selected range.

*Figure 7.8.1-1: Advanced Power Management*


Eight pairs of LED pins offer the option to be configured in channel bundling mode (LED0 & LED1, LED2 & LED3, ... LED14 & 
LED15). This bundling option is intended for advanced thermal management (please see figure 7.8.1-1), shifting power dissip-
ation to an external power sink resistor, which reduces the driver power consumption.
The channel current is regulated as a sum of currents in LED(x) and LED(x+1). The priority output LED(x) drives the current as 
long as the voltage headroom allows to. The bypass output LED(x+1) is used to deliver the remaining current flow. In any case
the bypass output LED(x+1) drives at least 5% of the sum of currents preventing the LED(x+1) from regulation performance 
lost. This implies, that the priority output LED(x) will drive at maximum 95% of the sum of currents.


The analog current sink channel bundling with prioritized current sum regulation can be enabled per LED driver pair using the
STANDALONE.ISINK_BUNDLE configuration value. In case, an LED driver pair is configured to be bundled like described 
before, the PWM channel combine has to be set up according to this to obtain phase-aligned PWM pulses with equal pulse 
lengths for bundled LED channels. Also BIN_GAIN_X, BIN_CLASS_ENABLE_X and PWMIN_ENABLE_X have to be configured 
the same for both channels.

The analog current sink channel bundling with prioritized current sum regulation can be enabled per LED driver pair using the
STANDALONE.ISINK_BUNDLE configuration value. In case, an LED driver pair is configured to be bundled like described 
before, the PWM channel combine has to be set up according to this to obtain phase-aligned PWM pulses with equal pulse 
lengths for bundled LED channels. Also BIN_GAIN_X, BIN_CLASS_ENABLE_X and PWMIN_ENABLE_X have to be configured 
the same for both channels.


For LED channels in analog bundling mode, the LED current, DAC range and PWM pulse length need to be configured the 
same for upper and lower channel to provide a consistent behavior of analog bundled LED channel pairs.

**7.8.2 LED Current Derating**


To protect the device from thermal damage, an automatic LED current derating is implemented. Two independent types of 
device internal (LED supply and device temperature) measurement based derating functions can be configured to derate the 
LED current between a start and stop value, as shown in the following figures. The derating is implemented as a nominal LED 
current dependent percental function, which means that larger currents are more derated than smaller currents from an 
absolute point of view. The LED supply and VT (device temperature) derating configuration values found below can be used 
to configure the desired range and gain values. The LED supply measurement is done using the direct amplification
AMEAS_VS and AMEAS_PWMIN paths, and the derating start and stop values have to be set according to this amplification 
factor.
The device also offers the possibility to derate depending on the BUS_DERATE_GAIN value controlled by the external micro-
controller using the bus interface.
The overall LED current derating factor is defined as the product of the 3 derating factors mentioned above.

**7.8.3 LED Binning**


To support different LED bin classes per device, a general LED bin factor can be configured per LED using the BIN_GAIN_X val-
ues.


Separate to this fixed bin configuration, the voltage drop over an external resistor connected to an LED pin can be evaluated 
for LED binning. The pin used for this evaluation can be selected using the BIN_CLASS_CONFIG.pin_sel value. A 100 percent 
PWM duty cycle and a sink current configuration value regarding BIN_CLASS_CONFIG.current_sel is used to drive this pin if 
bin class evaluation is enabled using BIN_CLASS_CONFIG.enable bit.


The following figure shows an example of LED binning with an external resistor.


**Note: the voltage over the external resistor is used for bin class evaluation. Relevant value in BUS_STATUS is the **
**"RESULT_VDIF_x" for the selected LED channel.**

Separate to this fixed bin configuration, the voltage drop over an external resistor connected to an LED pin can be evaluated

*Figure 7.8.3-1: Example LED Binning with an external resistor*


A table of 4 bin class levels (BIN_CLASS_LEVEL_x values) can be used to distinct between 5 bin classes with separate bin gain 
values (BIN_CLASS_GAIN_x values). The ADC measurement value of the pin to be evaluated is compared to the specified 
levels, the resistor value related bin class gain is determined and applied to the LEDs selected, using the 
BIN_CLASS_ENABLE_x values.
When the BIN_CLASS_ENABLE_x bit of an LED channel is configured as 1, the related general LED bin factor is not used and 
only the evaluated bin class gain is applied.


The following figure shows an example bin class table with resistor values selected from the E12 series.
In this example the external resistor is supplied with a current of 16mA.
The external resistor is evaluated once every 5ms and 3 adjacent sample values are filtered using a median filter algorithm 
(the last 3 values including the current value are sorted and the middle value is taken) before bin class gain selection.


The bin adoption is implemented as a LED current factor to reduce or raise the LED current depending on the LED bin class to 
achieve a uniform LED luminance of LEDs connected to a single driver device and between LEDs connected to different LED 
driver devices.

**7.8.3.1 Binning Groups**
The device supports up to two independent "Binning Groups" for the resistor based binning, that means that up to two LED 
driver channels can be configured as binning input pins. Each LED must only be assigned to one of the groups.


Each binning group has its own set of registers for:
•
 BIN_CLASS_CONFIG: current configuration, driver channel selection
•
 BIN_CLASS_ENABLE_x: LED to group assignment
•
 BIN_CLASS_GAIN_x: LED current gain factors per level
Both groups share the settings for:
•
 BIN_CLASS_LEVEL_x: binning class level definition
**Note:**
Configuration registers for binning group 0 are named BIN_CLASS_*.
Configuration registers for binning group 1 are named BIN_CLASS_1_*.


**7.8.4 Current Calculation Sequence**


The following diagrams show how the current calculation for each LED current sink is handled.
To avoid saturation effects do not exceed at any step the maximum current setting value of 1023 (0x3FF).
It is recommended to limit BIN_GAIN_X values to 1.9 for upper and 1.5 for lower range LEDs.

*Figure 7.9.1-1: Measurement System*


The centre of the measurement system is a 10 Bit SAR ADC.
With the ADC, it is possible to convert:


•
 LED voltage of each channel (prescaled and saturated)
•
 LED current of each channel
•
 Internal temperature-sensor voltage
•
 VDD5 voltage
•
 VS voltage (full range)
•
 PWMIN_HP voltage (full range)
•
 PWMIN_LP voltage (full range)
•
 A sample and hold (S&H) buffer voltage


3 inputs to the measurement system can be send to a sample and hold buffer. These are:


•
 VS voltage (prescaled and saturated)
•
 PWMIN_HP voltage (prescaled and saturated)
•
 PWMIN_LP voltage (prescaled and saturated)


LED(x) voltage and its supply can be sampled at the same time, and conversion of them can be done afterwards in series.
The diagnosis module will do a digital subtraction of the two results and compare it against the short detection threshold.

## 16 Channel Automotive LED Driver with Bus Interface 
** **
## E522.59 


PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


**7.10 Diagnosis**


The device implements diagnosis features to detect open or short conditions of the connected LEDs via voltage measure-
ments on the related device pins.
An LED short condition means, that the LED driver pin is shorted with the LED supply net. An LED open condition means, that 
the LED driver pin is open and does not sink a significant current, e.g. caused by a broken LED or LED connection.


This diagnosis is implemented using once per PWM period ADC measurements of all LED channel voltages and their related 
supply voltages.


**Open/Short Evaluation Constraints**
An LED pin short condition evaluation has to be configured in STANDALONE configuration area and is only done and signalled 
in case of:


•
 VS supply is larger than the minimum VS supply level configured using VS_TOO_LOW
•
 LED related raw (non-offset-gain corrected) LED supply ADC measurement value is not saturated (LED supply is selected 


using the LED_SUPPLY_SEL_x (VS, PWMIN_LP or PWMIN_HP) values)


•
 Short detection for the pin is enabled (LED_SHORT_SEL_x and configures thresholds LED_SHORT_THR_x)
•
 PWM was active and valid (LED current slewing has finished) during ADC measurement


An LED pin voltage based open condition evaluation has to be configured in STANDALONE configuration area and is only done
and signalled in case of:


•
 VS supply is larger than the minimum VS supply level configured using VS_TOO_LOW
•
 Voltage based Open detection for the pin is enabled (LED_OPEN_SEL_x and configures thresholds LED_OPEN_THR_x)
•
 PWM was active and valid (LED current slewing has finished) during ADC measurement


Note: LED pins configured as binning inputs must not be enabled for open/short diagnosis.


**Open/Short Event Filter**
Every diagnosis result compare operation generates an event which is fed into an LED error filter.
Each LED channel implements its own error filter using a counter and a common error level value (DIAG_CONFIG.level).
In case of an LED error condition, the filter counter value is incremented by 1 if the counter values is smaller than the 
DIAG_CONFIG.level value. In case of an LED OK condition, the filter counter value is decremented by 1 if the error counter is 
larger than 0.
When the filter counter value reaches the DIAG_CONFIG.level value, an LED channel error flag is set and kept until the filter 
counter value reaches 0 again. When the filter counter value reaches 0, the LED channel error flag is cleared.


If STANDALONE.DIAG_CONFIG.clear_on_vs_too_low is set, the error counters will be cleared if VS_TOO_LOW is active.

PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


*Figure 7.10-1: Open and Short Diagnosis Filter Behavior*


**7.10.1 Diagnosis Groups and Pins**


The device provides two independent diagnosis groups. Each LED Driver Pin can be assigned to one of theses groups. All of 
the groups can be individually configured using the configuration options in STANDALONE area. Only if a LED Pin is assigned 
to one of the diagnosis group it will take part in group specific behaviour, e.g. single lamp mode (SLM).


Diagnosis group 0 and 1 can be configured to be linked to diagnosis Pins (DIAG0/1) with the related evaluation logic shown in 
the figure below.
If the related LED0/DIAG0 or LED1/DIAG1 pin is selected to behave as a diagnosis pin (DIAG_CONFIG.diag0/1_sel = 1), LED 
channel error flag states are output at this diagnosis pin depending on the DIAG0/1_CONFIG.enable and DIAG_CURRENT.sel 
settings.


**Diagnosis Modes of Behaviour**
The device implements different modes of behaviour depending on the DIAG group configuration:


•
 diag_enable = 1, diag_sel = 0, slm = 0:


•
 Device internal only diagnosis information evaluation
•
 The related LED/DIAG pin will not drive diagnosis state and can be used as LED driver pin
•
 In case of an active diagnosis error flag:


•
 The corresponding LED driver is switched to a retry measurement state


•
 diag_enable = 1, diag_sel = 0, slm = 1:


•
 Device internal only diagnosis information evaluation
•
 The related LED/DIAG pin will not drive diagnosis state and can be used as LED driver pin
•
 In case of an active diagnosis error flag:


•
 The corresponding LED driver is switched to a retry measurement state
•
 All LED drivers of the related diagnosis group will be switched off (Device Single Lamp Mode)


•
 diag_enable = 1, diag_sel = 1, slm = 0:


•
 The related LED/DIAG pin will drive diagnosis state (used as DIAG pin)
•
 In case of an active diagnosis error flag:


•
 The corresponding LED driver is switched to a retry measurement state


•
 In case of an incoming active diagnosis state:


•
 This information will be ignored


•
 diag_enable = 1, diag_sel = 1, slm = 1:


•
 The related LED/DIAG pin will drive diagnosis state (used as DIAG pin)
•
 In case of an active diagnosis error flag:


•
 The corresponding LED driver is switched to a retry measurement state
•
 All LED drivers of the related diagnosis group will be switched off (System Single Lamp Mode)


•
 In case of an incoming active diagnosis state:


•
 All LED drivers of the related diagnosis group will be switched off (System Single Lamp Mode)

## 16 Channel Automotive LED Driver with Bus Interface 
** **
## E522.59 


PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


The LED channel retry measurement state is used to recover LED channels from active error state. In this state the LED chan-
nel is switched ON for the minimum time needed to do LED channel retry ADC measurement.


Please note, that in SLM mode all LED channel drivers of a diagnosis group are switched off (LED driver off), if at least one LED
of this diagnosis group is in error state, except the LEDs which cause this error state (LED driver on, used for retry measure-
ments).
This lowers the device current consumption in OPEN/SHORT error state, which allows to detect this error state (if all device 
LED driver channels are combined in a single diagnosis group) using a very low current consumption compare threshold.


For the generation of retry pulses in BUS mode it is required that the corresponding BUS_CONFIG pulse is greater than zero, 
otherwise no retry pulses will be generated. In HPFB, LPFB, Direct PWM and BUS timeout modes the retry pulses are gener-
ated independend of the selected PWM duty cycle.


Note: Diagnosis groups can be configured using the DIAGx_CONFIG.enable values.
Note: Always exclude diagnosis pins and LED binning read-in pin from diagnosis groups defined by STANDALONE.DIAG0_CON-
FIG_0_7, DIAG0_CONFIG_8_15, DIAG1_CONFIG_0_7 and DIAG1_CONFIG_8_15 values.


The diagnosis evaluation logic shown in the figure below, behaves as follows:


•
 In case slm is 0, the LED error flag states are fed through the SLM logic.
•
 In case slm is 1, the output vector of the SLM logic has only two states:


•
 When any LED error flag is active, all bits of the vector are set to 1.
•
 When no LED error flag is active, all bits of the vector are set to 0.


Note: diag_ie is generated inside the device from diag_sel and slm: diag_ie = diag_sel & slm

**7.10.2 Analog Bundled Mode Diagnosis**


In analog bundled mode, the ILED diagnosis is not possible. This means, that the ILED open evaluation will be disabled by the 
device for all analog bundled channels. In case the device also drives non-bundled LED channels, the ILED open evaluation for
these channels will be done regarding the ILED open threshold configuration value.


**7.10.3 Standalone Area**


Depending on the application, different LED supply concepts are possible to implement. To do a correct open and short dia-
gnosis, the device needs to know the LED supply relation. This can be configured using the LED_SUPPLY_SEL_x values.
For open diagnosis, three different voltage levels can be configured using the LED_OPEN_THR_x values, and assigned to LED 
channels using the LED_OPEN_SEL_x values.
For short diagnosis, three different voltage levels can be configured using the LED_SHORT_THR_x values, and assigned to LED 
channels using the LED_SHORT_SEL_x values.

## 16 Channel Automotive LED Driver with Bus Interface 
** **
## E522.59 


PRODUCTION DATA – May 10, 2023


An LED open condition is detected if the LED pin voltage is below it's related LED_OPEN_THR_x level. In case of at least one 
enabled open condition, a common open error flag is set in the EVENT_STATUS value.
An LED short condition is detected if the LED related supply voltage minus the LED pin voltage is below its related 
LED_SHORT_THR_x level. In case of at least one enabled short condition, a common short error flag is set in the 
EVENT_STATUS value.
An LED short condition is only signalized in case the sampled ADC supply and LED pin values are not saturated.


The device power supply can be observed using level values, which can be configured using the VS_TOO_LOW and VS_CRIT-
ICAL values.


•
 When VS voltage falls below the VS_TOO_LOW level, an error flag is set in the EVENT_STATUS value.
•
 When VS voltage is larger than the VS_CRITICAL level, an error flag is set in the EVENT_STATUS value.
•
 When VT temperate value is larger than the VT_CRITICAL level, an error flag is set in the EVENT_STATUS value.

**7.10.4 Bus Status Area**


The ADC measurement result values are stored by the device in the following data structure even like the open, short and 
device event status flags.
The EVENT_STATUS flags are captured and held until the value is read via the bus communication interface. At this moment 
the event flags are cleared automatically.


**ADC open and short measurements**


The ADC will perform VLED, VDIF and ILED measurements independent of the open and short thresholds and analog bundling
configuration and provide the data in the BUS_STATUS area. This makes it possible to implement a bus master driven open 
and short evaluation without using the device internal open and short evaluation logic.

## 3 Channel Automotive LED Driver 
** **
## E522.60 


PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**Features**


•
 Supply Voltage Range 4.5V to 36V (max. 40V)
•
 Three Linear Current Drivers (up 200mA each)
•
 Parallel Output Operation for up to 600mA
•
 Thermal Management Option per Channel
•
 Integrated 3-Phase PWM Generator


for e.g. Tail/Stop Lighting


•
 Diagnosis supported for


•
 LED Drivers (incl. configurable Thresholds)
•
 IR Current Configuration
•
 Junction Temperature including Derating


•
 Configurable Fault-Handling Modes


•
 "Failure Feedback Mode" (FFM)
•
 "Single Lamp Behaviour" (SLM)


•
 Diagnostic RUN Bus to link ICs into Clusters


e.g. built using E522.60/E522.8x/E522.9x Products


•
 External Reference Voltage / Derating Supported
•
 Low-Power Standby / Sleep Mode
•
 Narrow SO16 Package with Exposed Pad
•
 AEC-Q100 Automotive Qualification


**Applications**


•
 Automotive LED Lighting e.g. Rear Lighting


Turn Indicators, Day-Running Light


•
 Medium Current Interior Lighting
•
 Industrial LED Applications


**Ordering Information**


**Product ID**
**Ambient Temp.**
**Package**


E52260A96E -40°C to +125°C
SOIC-16n EP


**General Description**


E522.60 provides high-voltage linear current drivers suit-
able for e.g. LED lighting applications up to 3x200mA. 
E522.60 features 'one-resistor' common current config-
uration at reduced effort. Integrated diagnostics support 
automotive requirements together with a fault-bus 
"RUN" to link ICs.


Two external configurable modes of fault handling allow
•
 "Failure Feedback Mode" FFM operating channels in 


case of errors, with error signalization


•
 "Single Lamp Mode" turning all linked E522.60 chan-


nels 'off' in case of errors


Integrated phase-shifted PWM dutycycle generation 
simplifies supply-line filtering in case of dimmed opera-
tion. Low-component-count switching between continu-
ous operation (e.g. STOP light) and PWM dimmed oper-
ation (e.g. TAIL light) is supported.


Robust power management is provided per channel to 
extend the usable range of supply voltage and/or power 
- combined with excellent low-drop performance and 
flexibility in LED voltage per channel. Simple shunt res-
istors share power dissipation with the IC package to 
reduce temperature of the PCB hotspots.


Derating for internal reference voltage increases robust-
ness of E522.60 systems in case of abnormal operation 
conditions. Further flexibility for e.g. advanced thermal 
handling is provided by analog reference voltages via 
high-voltage ENA input.

1)
 Higher VS capacitance allows longer storage of error status information in case of typical Power-Supply-Dimming. Actual battery filter design 
needs to take further application specific parameters into account (e.g. supply line inductance, ESD & EMC)
2)
 ENA pre-resistor in particular recommended to avoid negative current injections e.g. during ISO7637 supply pulses
3)
 If selection interface IR is used with higher resistive values take a reduced accuracy into account. Pay attention to the 'open' state detection 
limit IIR,OPEN for IR configuration
4)
 Use of IR capacitance is optional e.g. to increase EMC robustness
5)
 LED capacitance recommended to improve EMC/ESD/Pulse behavior. Functionaly not required in terms of compensation or stability. Consider
the LED-string voltage and startup tolerance time in tERR,DEB1 to avoid LED glowing during e.g. re-diagnosis
6)
 Recommended to limit DC capacitance to avoid phase shift between V
VS
 and V
DC
 during transients. Higher capacitance is possible if formed as
capacitive divider between VS-DC and DC-GND
7)
 To avoid DC divider impact on accuracy consider input impedance of DC interface to reduce systematic offset
8)
 DC dutycycle PWM generator is recommended to be used either in PWM range as described by D
DC,PWM,TYP
 or in modes for 0% (DC pin

## E522.60

9)
 During ENA dimming there are inherent delays for e.g. ENA comparison, RUN pin risetime and LED
X
 driver activation. This delay contributes 
to PWM linearity (see also example in "Single ENA Dimming Pulse" in chapter 5). In case of DC usage the dimming frequency is generated 
within the IC
10)
 Minimum ON-time per channel recommended to ensure proper diagnosis and/or fault recovery. Shorter times are possible if (re-)diagnosis is 
not needed
11)
 SLM is an output of E522.60 and is recommended to be driven by the IC only (or to be shared with compatible ICs providing this SLM outputs
as well, see also N
SLM,BUS
)
12)
 Compatible ICs for sharing the SLM interface in a bus-structure are e.g. E522.80/81/82/83 and E522.90/91/92/93. Please also refer to those 
datasheets e.g. for according pull-up/pull-down currents
13)
 SLM capacitance leads to delays in fault-handling mode detection (FFM/SLM mode). Assumed product use-case is without capacitor at SLM. 
Nevertheless C
SLM
 is not limited by device functionality and can be chosen higher on users behalf (e.g. for EMC protection)
14)
 High capacitance values are possible, but lead to additional delay between rising edge at ENA and state change to active operation
15)
 For operation close to maximum recommended junction temperature please in particular consider the thermal derating mechanism of 
E522.60

# f o r  B l u e  B i n a r i e s ,  C h e n n a i  -  C O N F I D E N T I A L


## 3 Channel Automotive LED Driver 
** **
## E522.60 


PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**4 Functional Description **


**4.1 Overview**


E522.60 provides a high functional compatibility to previous generations E522.8x/E522.9x LED driver families. It 
has a higher current rating up to 3x 200mA or parallel operation at 1x600mA. To reduce component effort a 'single-
resistor' current setting is available. Users can choose e.g. from different V
VS
 related thresholds for LED 'open' 
detection or even realize a single-LED short-detection using various under-voltage thresholds for LED
X
.


PWM dimming is supported in two ways:
Either PWM is generated using suitable signal at ENA (dimming all channels in parallel) or by using the built-in gen-
erator at DC (to gain the benefit of easier supply filtering due to interleaved channel activation). In particular rear-
light applications will benefit from the integrated precise PWM dutycycle generator (omitting the need for dedicated 
external signal generators).


As in E522.8x/9x various diagnostic features are provided to meet automotive requirements, together with a com-
munication interface named RUN. Using RUN as a bus is intended to link additional compatible ICs to form fault-
reaction-combined clusters of more than three LED strings. ICs combined in this way commonly turn 'on'/'off' in 
case of a detected faults (e.g. to turn all drivers in a cluster 'off' in case of a single string fault). Other Elmos ICs of 
e.g. E522.8x or E522.9x families are 'RUN-compatible'.

As in E522.8x/9x various diagnostic features are provided to meet automotive requirements, together with a com-
munication interface named RUN. Using RUN as a bus is intended to link additional compatible ICs to form fault-
reaction-combined clusters of more than three LED strings. ICs combined in this way commonly turn 'on'/'off' in 
case of a detected faults (e.g. to turn all drivers in a cluster 'off' in case of a single string fault). Other Elmos ICs of 
e.g. E522.8x or E522.9x families are 'RUN-compatible'.


Two configurable modes of operation allow
•
 either "Failure Feedback Mode" FFM (operating remaining LED
X
 channels in case of an error detection)
•
 or in "Single Lamp Mode" (turning all linked E522.60´s channels "off" in case of error detections)


**Overview & Document Links:**


•
 A detailed overview of functional states and transitions is given in 4.2
•
 Integrated PWM generator is decribed in 4.3
•
 Mode configurations FFM or SLM are described in 4.4
•
 More information on the LED
X
 drivers and power management can be found in 4.5
•
 For details on the LED
X
 configuration via IR interface see 4.6
•
 Diagnostic features are located in 4.7
•
 Dimensioning formulas can be found at 4.8
•
 For reference the ESD principle of E52260A is shown in 4.9
•
 Typical performance figures are shown in 5
•
 Exemplary application topologies are presented in 6

•
 activated but faulty LED channels are indexed by 'y' (activated but showing any error, thus being disabled)
•
 deactivated LED channels are indexed by 'z' (deactivation e.g. by CH_SEL config or DC PWM dimming)

PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**4.3 DC Dutycycle Generator**
For PWM dimming E522.60 offers two options:


•
 Use of ENA interface as a digital input (switch between sleep-mode and active operation)


•
 All channels commonly react to this way of PWM dimming (see also statediagram in 4.2-1)
•
 Thus this scheme provides flexibility to use external frequency generators
•
 Frequency can be almost freely defined by the application designer
•
 This scheme is typically used for power-supply dimming approaches (by sensing the supply line voltage using 


ENA & keeping latest internal state with the remaining energy stored in C
VS
 capacitors)


•
 Alternatively in E522.60 the DC dutycycle configuration pin can be used as shown in 4.3-1


•
 Optional as either digital high-voltage (V
VS
 level) dimming input or analog input
•
 For analog operation a resistor divider between VS and GND connected to DC configures the intended duty-


cycle
•
 Internal circuitry derives the PWM signals per enabled channel
•
 LED
X
 channels are operated 'phase-shifted' in this scheme to reduce supply noise


•
 Applications like TAIL/STOP can switch the DC input to GND for brake-light indication

# f o r  B l u e  B i n a r i e s ,  C h e n n a i  -  C O N F I D E N T I A L


## 3 Channel Automotive LED Driver 
** **
## E522.60 


PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**4.4 SLM Interface**


The pin SLM can be used to distinguish between single lamp behaviour or failure feedback mode. The basic setup 
of this pin is shown in 4.4-1.


**Single Lamp Mode**
 (SLM)
is characterized by switching all LED
X
 channels 'off' in case of a single failure on any channel (also known as "one-
out-all-out" behavior). This mode allows to form a network of LEDs to behave in a comparable manner to a single 
bulb lamp. Other E522.60 (contributing to the same light-functionality) should be connected to each-other via RUN 
to allow standby mode in other ICs as well. Simple configuration to operate E522.60 in this way is to leave the pin 
SLM 'open' (so that the voltage level V
SLM
 exceeds V
SLM,HIGH
).


**Failure Feedback Mode**
 (FFM)
is typically used to provide status feedback to some external circuitry, e.g. a microcontroller/outage circuitry/body 
control module (and/or to provide a higher degree of independence between LED
X
 channels regarding fault-reac-
tion). In this mode of operation a detected fault can be indicated while other non-faulty channels (of the same IC) 
remain operated. Note that the RUN pin is driven 'low' in FFM, too.

**Failure Feedback Mode**
 (FFM)
is typically used to provide status feedback to some external circuitry, e.g. a microcontroller/outage circuitry/body 
control module (and/or to provide a higher degree of independence between LED
X
 channels regarding fault-reac-
tion). In this mode of operation a detected fault can be indicated while other non-faulty channels (of the same IC) 
remain operated. Note that the RUN pin is driven 'low' in FFM, too.


To use E522.60 in FFM one recommended way is to use an NPN type bipolar transistor and connect it´s base to 
SLM (of course alternatively a direct connection of SLM pin to GND is possible). The threshold V
SLM,HIGH
 is designed
high enough to detect V
SLM
 < V
SLM,HIGH
, e.g. held low by the base-emitter voltage of the external NPN device. Other 
E522.60 in the application can share the same bipolar base to reduce device count (wired-OR).

PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**Further SLM Application Hints & Remarks:**


•
 A maximum of four E522.60 SLM interfaces connected in this wired-OR bus is recommended
•
 SLM interface evaluates the pin´s voltage level (compared to V
SLM,HIGH
) only in case a fault is detected by the IC

recover in case the fault condition is cleared).

## 3 Channel Automotive LED Driver 
** **
## E522.60 


PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


The 
**LED**
**X**
 driver 'open fault' threshold is relative to the actual current configured at IR (see ILEDx,OPEN). As a 
second condition this detection is only active if the supply V
VS
 is (without hysteresis) higher than the selected 
V
VS,DIAG,1/2/3/4
 (configured at OD_EN).


A configurable LED
X
 output under-voltage monitoring allows to detect e.g. short-circuits or overload at selectable 
V
LED,X
 levels. Considering a given load (e.g. versus temperature and/or binning) allows to select the best suitable 
threshold via SC_TH to potentially detect single-LED short-circuits, too.


**Loss of VS or ENA**
 connection for a E522.60 is propagated via RUN being set to 'low' (to cover e.g. 'open' faults at
these pins).


**IR**
 is monitored for currents that are too high/low. A fault at IR is considered a fault on all active LED
X
 channels. Re-
diagnosis is triggered by the (re-)activation of any channel. During FFM the IR driver is only active if at least one 
LED
X
 channel is active.


The 
**DC Interface**
 is suitable as analog and high-voltage digital dimming input. Please note that a static deactiva-
tion of LED
X
 drivers by a 'DC high' condition is considered a fault by the IC. The applied timeout (see parameter
tDC,OFF,FAULT) is used to diagnose e.g. short-to-battery faults in 'Active Normal/FFM' modes of operation (see
4.2-1). It shall avoid e.g. un-detected loss of lighting functionality in this particular fault case. DC timeout leads to 
indication via RUN bus and SLM interface. This fault is cleared if LED
X
 operation is resumed or if the IC transitions 
into 'Sleep Mode' or 'Standby Mode'.

The 
**DC Interface**
 is suitable as analog and high-voltage digital dimming input. Please note that a static deactiva-
tion of LED
X
 drivers by a 'DC high' condition is considered a fault by the IC. The applied timeout (see parameter
tDC,OFF,FAULT) is used to diagnose e.g. short-to-battery faults in 'Active Normal/FFM' modes of operation (see
4.2-1). It shall avoid e.g. un-detected loss of lighting functionality in this particular fault case. DC timeout leads to 
indication via RUN bus and SLM interface. This fault is cleared if LED
X
 operation is resumed or if the IC transitions 
into 'Sleep Mode' or 'Standby Mode'.


**Fault Clear Conditions**
 in general are as follows:
•
 A diagnosis cycle longer than tERR,DEB1 shows removal of the erroneous conditions
•
 VS under-voltage reset, leading to IC reset
•
 LED2/LED3: if statically disabled via CH_SEL the according error entries are cleared after 64 diagnostic cycles
•
 a DC timeout fault is recovered by DC request for any LED channel or by IC deactivation (e.g. via ENA)


In general if a fault is detected, it is stored for selective re-diagnosis. Dimming at either ENA or by DC interface 
PWM generation does not delete this information.
LED
X
 re-diagnosis in case of static (un-dimmed) operation is performed on a regular time-basis of TERR,REDIAG 
to allow recovery of faulty loads / LEDs. These re-diagnosis cycles are also performed on LED
2,3
 even if these are 
disabled via CH_SEL. The amount of re-tries in this special case is limited (see Clear-Conditions above).


*Hint on SC_TH and potential 'LED Glowing' during Re-Diagnosis:*


E522.60 is designed to build applications that prevent 'LED Glowing' during re-diagnosis. This works best for V
SC_TH
 
= V
GND
. As an advanced feature SC_TH allows to configure thresholds higher than 1.5V (see parameters in 3.6-1). 
This provides the advantage to potentially identify a 'single-LED' short-circuit in e.g. 2-LED applications. Neverthe-
less please note, that in such cases the remaining single LED will most probably light-up during diagnosis based on
t
ERR,DEB1
.

*Figure 6.1-1: Single Lamp Cluster Application Principle*


The drawing shows a SLM cluster of 2 or more ICs linked to form 6 or more channels of LED lighting.


Additional notes on this topology:
•
 Battery line is assumed to be driven with some PWM signal between a positive supply and GND
•
 Capacitors at VS store energy during the PWM 'low' phases
•
 A resistive divider at ENA supports three advantages:


•
 it provides a pull-down to GND if e.g. the supply line is driven by a high-side driver only
•
 the divider can be used to scale VS for an analog under-voltage derating or thermal derating
•
 in case of automotive enviroments with reverse voltage requirements it can limit the current injected into ENA 


pins within SOA and help to avoid an additional reverse polarity protection


•
 This example uses standard configurations with low additional component/PCB efforts
•
 LED capacitors shown are optional but recommended for automotive enviroments

In this example a white reverse light has to be driven, here two white LEDs at up to 600mA. All outputs are in a par-
allel setup using one option to combine the power-sharing resistors. Alternatively either the LEDxB outputs can be 
shorted to each-other or only one shunt can be used (with sufficient power-rating).


Additional notes on this topology:
•
 in automotive enviroments with typical supplies the overall linear power would range at typ. 14V*0.6A or 8.4W. 


Thermal design of the PCB up to maximum supply voltage is challenging - the use of multiple thermal shunts sig-
nificantly improves options to distribute PCB hot-spots


•
 Dimming is not used here, also all configuration pins use default values based on 'component-less' options
•
 a TVS (transient-voltage-suppressor) at the input helps to sustain e.g. ISO7637 pulses in automotive enviro-


ments


•
 non-automotive enviroments may need other protective structures to fulfill all application requirements and 


standards


•
 Optional: 'Failure Feedback Mode' is used to operate LED
X

detections (to improve availability in such cases)

*Figure 6.3-1: STOP/BRAKE & TAIL Light Application Principle*


Rear-lighting often involves a backward compatible structure with two supply lines, one for the TAIL light (during 
drive cycles) and one for STOP (BRAKE) lights which are to be significantly brighter than the TAIL function. To 
avoid a topology with two independent drivers the supply is 'or-ed' by diodes to one or more ICs as needed to form 
strings.


The STOP light shall have priority and always operate in 100% 'on' mode for the LEDs, while TAIL lights are typic-
ally operated at 10%...15% dimming cycles only. To provide this priority of STOP over TAIL the external switching 
circuitry is suggested, switching the DC PWM divider to GND as soon as STOP exceeds a certain voltage level. 
This voltage level is defined in the example by the amplification of the pre-divider and the bipolar junction of the 
NPN.


Additional notes on this topology:
•
 SLM pin stays 'low' (due to NPN) and the application operates in FFM mode
•
 in automotive typically a feedback about fault detection is required. In the example a reverse polarity protected 


NPN with capacitive EMC filtering at it´s base is used for that purpose (OUTAGE driver stages typically provide 
further/more complex requirements)


•
 The SC_TH is configured as 'open'. This allows to set an undervoltage-threshold for the two LEDs that typically 


is suitable to detect a 'single-LED-short-circuit'. Please check the tolerance of LEDs versus current & binning & 
temperature to identify the best suited threshold for such a use-case


•
 One shared TVS (transient-voltage-suppressor) diode is used for both supplies TAIL and STOP/BRAKE

*Figure 6.4-1: Principle of a STOP/TAIL Light, Variant*


Another variant of STOP/TAIL applications in this example uses only a single supply wire. The two signals STOP/
TAIL do not need to provide the full load current capability per interface. Single-supply allows standard battery filter-
ing without the need for two power-inputs.


As in the previous example the STOP light has priority over the TAIL functionality. Nevertheless, both signals first 
of all are independent. Here it is assumed that it is beneficial to provide feedback via SLM interface about the non-
operational state of the lighting functionality (e.g. to validate the capability to indicate or to detect e.g. DC short-cir-
cuit to VS). If the status 'all LEDs off' shall not be handled as a fault it is optional to only activate 522.60 by or´ing 
the two wires labelled TAIL/STOP at ENA interface (e.g. using diodes).


Additional notes on this topology:
•
 SLM reports about detected faults or DC-deactivated light functionality longer than timeout (neither TAIL nor 


STOP present)


•
 Signal wires for TAIL/STOP instead of power-lines provide flexibility at the lighting functionality connector and 


application supply line filters


•
 Reduced current spikes in the supply lines during turn 'on' due to static supply

*Figure 6.5-1: LED Driver for Long LED Strings Application Principle*


Some topologies use pre-boosters to provide a stabilized supply above typical (battery-)supply level. To optimize 
such a system a reduced number of LED driving circuits introduces more LEDs per string. Operating range up to 
36V for E522.60 can be used to design such applications.


Additional notes on this topology:
•
 Analog interfacing block might be build comparable to the STOP/TAIL application shown in chapter 6.3
•
 PWM generation is integrated in E522.60 - avoiding the need for additional PWM generators or timers like e.g. 


NE555 compatible devices


•
 In this product there is no reference derating interfering with the high supply voltage (in contrast to other mostly 


compatible devices like E522.80 which provide this feature for operation at 12V-battery nets)


•
 Choosing highest 'open-detection' enable threshold via OD_EN pin supports longer LED strings
•
 Outage stages typically provide fault-feedback with battery supply level. Due to the user specific set of require-


ments and solutions it not shown here in detail


•
 The SMPS part is not subject to this documentation. Nevertheless booster ICs like e.g. E522.31/32 of Elmos can


be used for this purpose. Please check the Elmos website or contact your key-account manager for more details 
on those products

*Figure 6.7-1: Principles in Battery Line Filters*


An automotive battery line filter is usually quite complex and closely designed to application OEM requirements by 
developers. One common property to be considered for simple rear-lighting is an inductive supply cable (due to 
wire-length/distance and backward compatibility to former topologies usually >5µH or more are taken into account).
It is assumed that users of E522.60 are well-experienced in designing such filters in accordance to application 
requirements.

## 3 Channel Automotive LED Driver 
** **
## E522.60 


PRELIMINARY INFORMATION – Apr 14, 2022


**Hints on battery line filters using E522.60 and family members:**


Here are some hints on supply line filtering (not claiming completeness of considerations)


•
 the supply line is inductive. In particular in combination with ceramic capacitor types there is a high probability for


high quality factors / high-amplitude voltage ringing in the supply line
•
 independent of ICs or IC vendors this might lead to additional emission and/or distortions. Consider the use of 


a R-C network with capacitance larger than the sum of other functional low-ESR caps connected to the VS 
supply net
•
 the capacitance in this part of the filter typically scales with the total amount of VS ceramic capacitance (typ.


capacitance values chosen are higher by a factor of 3x to 5x)


•
 Resistance can be defined by experiment (using battery artifical network, LISN or simple SPICE simulators 


available on the market). Several Ohms are typical resulting resistance values


•
 phase-shifted PWM generation of E522.60 via DC helps to reduce the excitation of the input net. In contrast to


that a common dimming of all channels in parallel leads to increased low-frequency distortions and needs to 
be covered by higher capacitance at VS


•
 supply lines are subject to ISO pulses based on ISO7637. Typical TVS used are SMB packaged types, some 


TVS vendors provide sufficient performance even in SMA


•
 best suited reverse polarity protection depends on the TVS usage:


•
 if a bi-directional TVS is placed at the connector on the battery line connection of the PCB the reversed 


voltage is quite limited (e.g. during ISO pulses 1 and 3a). If it is possible to use a schottky device this can sig-
nificantly improve the applications low-voltage performance for starter- and cranking pulses (by reduction of 
overall-dropout voltage from battery to LEDs)


•
 if the TVS is not used (or placed on the inner part of the circuitry) behind the reverse protection a breakdown-


voltage of several hundred volt is commonly used. In this case bipolar diodes are an intuitive choice


•
 ESD and EMC/BCI robustness can be improved by a capacitor at the battery input of the PCB. Such a capacitor 


needs to take the maximum voltages of clamps & reverse protection into account - and depending on OEM 
requirements might need protection against single-point fault of 'short-circuit' (e.g. by so-called 'open-mode' 
capacitors or serial connection of two capacitors)


•
 a minimum resistance to GND is typically needed for the battery net. Re-use of this resistor as a divider for ENA 


could reduce component count on the PCB


•
 E522.60 and comparable ICs do not need high VS capacitance for their operation itself (additional application 


specific requirements apply). The increased recommended value of typ. 330nF is intended for dimming opera-
tion, in particular in case of 'power-supply dimming' to store fault-information during the battery-line 'low' phase 
(assuming dimming at 200Hz or higher)
•
 if LED glowing during re-diagnosis in 'power-supply dimming' applications occurs it might be caused by insuffi-


cient VS capacitance or too slow falling edge of PWM battery supply (or derived ENA signal)


•
 higher PWM frequencies of at least 400Hz help to reduce the interference/flickering regarding camera-based 


visibility. Using DC-based internal PWM (in phase-shifted operation) provides an effective frequency of 
approx. 1.3kHz in three-LED channel configurations

## 16 Channel Rearlight Driver - Standalone Version 
** **
## E522.88 


PRODUCT PREVIEW – Jan 21, 2022


**Features**


•
 Supply voltage range from 5V up to 32V
•
 16 programmable LED drivers up to 100mA
•
 LED driver current selection step size of 100uA
•
 8 custom sequences to control LED's using up to 5 dis-


crete signals


•
 OTP memory for storing individual LED channel configura-


tion


•
 1832 bytes of OTP memory for storing sequences to 


implement dynamic signalling and animations


•
 Sequences implemented using simple instructions
•
 10bit internal PWM generators for high brightness resolu-


tion


•
 Individual LED channel bin class brightness correction
•
 Optional binning with external resistors
•
 10bit ADC for LED open, short and system diagnosis
•
 Advanced device power management by channel bund-


ling option


•
 Customizable supply and temperature dependent LED 


current derating


•
 Single lamp mode behavior option
•
 I²C interface for programming customer application con-


figuration and scenarios


•
 Developed according ISO 26262, supports safety require-


ments with ASIL B


•
 Automotive qualification according to AEC-Q100


**Applications**


•
 Automotive interior and exterior light systems
•
 General LED Applications
•
 Basic stand alone LED light dynamic animations


**General Description**


The E522.88 is a multi-channel PWM driver for lighting 
applications. It provides 16 current sinks with an integrated 
10bit PWM generator for each channel. Each of the channels 
can be digitally configured to drive up to 100mA with a 
selectable slew rate.
The device provides a simple instruction set to control the 
LED channels. The instruction set can be used to generate up 
to eight unique light functions. These light functions can be 
triggered using up to five discrete pins. The device provides 
OTP memory to store the application specific sequences of 
instructions. The customer application configuration can be 
programmed into the device using the I²C bus interface.
An advanced device power management feature allows LED 
channel bundling with automatic current balancing with 
external resistors resulting in reduced device power dissipa-
tion.
Various diagnostic features, like LED open, short condition 
detection and temperature sensor, are provided to meet 
automotive requirements.
To protect the device from thermal damage, the device 
implements a configurable LED supply and device temperat-
ure dependent automatic LED current derating.

**1 Functional Safety**


The development of this product is based on a process according to ISO 26262 which has been certified to be compliant to 
ISO 26262 requirements and integrity levels up to ASIL D. Technical safety requirements for this product are rated ASIL B.
In order to achieve the IC target metrics for the appropriate ASIL, it is mandatory to consider the safety mechanisms and 
recommendations mentioned in the safety manual.


**1.1 Technical Safety Requirements**


Table 1.1-1: Technical safety requirement


**Property**
**Description**


ID
TSR1


Brief description
Provide predefined LED output signal corresponding to input data


ASIL
B


Detailed description
The state of the LED output channels shall be controlled, depending on input signals, in 
accordance with the predefined LED output data. The IC shall provide diagnosis informa-
tion.


Safe State
In case of any failure of the IC the device shall reset or give failure indication via Diag-Pin.


In case of a detected failure within external LED string the IC shall give failure information 
via Diag-Pin.


Fault Tolerant Time Interval
For single point faults a fault tolerant time of 300ms is assumed.
For latent faults, a detection within one driving cycle (i.e. during initial self test of the Item) 
is assumed to be compliant to the multiple point fault detection interval requirements.

**Explanation:**
•
I
LED
 describes the current which is digitally requested (incl. derating and binning). The register has a size of 10 bit. This corresponds to a maximum value of
1023 LSB or 102.3 mA.


•
Channel matching accuracy describes the matching of an individual channel against the average value of all channels programmed to same output 
current.
Overall accuracy describes matching of an individual channel against absolute value selected by its register.


•
All accuracy values are valid when lower range is selected for currents below 40mA and upper range is selected for currents above 40mA. When using 
analog channel bundling, the stated accuracy values are valid for current sums above 20mA of the two bundled channels.

## 16 Channel Rearlight Driver - Standalone Version 
** **
## E522.88 


PRODUCT PREVIEW – Jan 21, 2022


**7 Functional Description **


**7.1 System Introduction**


The E522.88A is a multi-channel PWM driver for lighting applications. It provides 16 current sinks with integrated 10bit PWM 
generator for each channel. Each driver can be used to drive external loads up to 100mA with a selectable LED current slew 
rate. All LED channels provide separate PWM duty cycle settings and high precision wide-range LED current configuration.
The device can support up to eight light functions using five discrete pins to trigger these light functions. There are two 
modes, main mode and animation mode, differentiated by the ANI_IN signal. The light function can be implemented using 
simple instructions. The device offers flexibility for light functions to be associated with available LED channels. A maximum 
of four light functions can execute in parallel.
Various diagnostic features, like LED open and short condition detection, are provided to meet automotive requirements.
An advanced device power management feature makes it possible to bundle LED channels and use an automatic current bal-
ancing to reduce device thermal dissipation.
To protect the device from thermal damage, it implements a configurable, LED supply and device temperature dependent, 
LED current derating.
The LED driver device can be used in a device group, configured to behave like a single lamp in case of an LED open or short 
condition. For this reason two diagnosis groups can be defined and used to connect the grouped LED driver devices.
The device offers a wide range of operating modes to cover different use cases.


*This document contains information on a product under development. Elmos Semiconductor SE reserves the right to change or discontinue this product without notice.*

**7.2 Device Startup**


**7.2.1 Device States**


*Figure 7.2.1-1: Device State Diagram*

 INIT-2


1. Initializes all hardware units as per configuration data.

the OTP.


•
 PROG


1. Programs the user data received from the I²C master into the OTP.
2. Power cycling is required to apply the programmed data.
3. This state is entered from INIT-2 only if OTP_DONE = 0.


•
 ACTIVE


1. Executes enabled sequences - reads PWM's and currents for active sequences (main or animation) from sequence 


database.


2. overrides PWM's and currents from the I²C Master, if available.
3. Applies binning, bundling and derating.
4. Enters CONFIG state on receiving config start request from I²C master, if validation is not locked.
5. This state is entered only if OTP_DONE = 1.


•
 CONFIG


1. This state is only available for factory debug and is not available to the user.
2. Changes the configuration in RAM registers on request from I²C master.
3. Enters INIT-2 state on receiving config stop request from I²C master.


•
 Note : Reset may be triggered from any of the device states.

 state START

**7.2.2 Device data handling**


The figure below shows the internal PWM pulse width and LED current configuration data handling. This data handling is 
done using DMA functionality and the Device Control Module.


During device startup:
The BUS_CONFIG area is initialized using some of the OTP data


Every time derating factor or LED binning factor changes:
LED current data from sequences is adapted using derating, LED binning, IDAC range and LED bundled mode factors, and then
written to the IDAC current reload data area.


Active LED driver stages will be measured for diagnosis and the ADC result data is written to the BUS_STATUS area.

## 16 Channel Rearlight Driver - Standalone Version 
** **
## E522.88 


PRODUCT PREVIEW – Jan 21, 2022


To assign unique device addresses to all LED driver devices connected to a common bus, the following procedure can be 
used:


1. Set one device PROG pin to active high level and restart at least this device via it's reset pin or a power cycle.
2. Access the device using the device address value 31 and device group 1.
3. Program a unique device address value (larger than 0, smaller than 31) to COM_DEV_ADDR.
4. Remove the PROG pin active high level and repeat these steps with all other devices.


Note: The last assigned device address can also be a 31.
Note: While PROG pin is set to "high", the LED channels 0 & 1 are switched off!


**7.3 Bus Interface**


**7.3.1 I²C Slave Bus Interface**


The I²C Slave Bus Interface allows access to the device configuration data and device status information. This is used to pro-
gram the user configuration in the device OTP memory. The I²C bus has direct access to the device RAM. The write to the OTP
areas is accomplished via a memory access protocol using read/write to these RAM areas. The I²C access is also used for 
device testing. This interface is not designed to be used in an application and is only meant for end of line programming of 
user configuration.


The following sections provide details of the protocol to configure user OTP area and the constraints that need to be fol-
lowed.


**7.3.1.1 I²C Interface Features**
•
 Serial bidirectional communication
•
 Standard-mode (100 kbit/s) support
•
 Fast-mode (400 kbit/s) support
•
 Single master only
•
 I²C standard START and STOP conditions
•
 I²C standard MSB first byte format, ACK and NACK


**7.3.1.2 I²C Protocol**
**Protocol Features:**


•
 frame based communication
•
 7 bit device address

The following sections provide details of the protocol to configure user OTP area and the constraints that need to be fol-
lowed.


**7.3.1.1 I²C Interface Features**
•
 Serial bidirectional communication
•
 Standard-mode (100 kbit/s) support
•
 Fast-mode (400 kbit/s) support
•
 Single master only
•
 I²C standard START and STOP conditions
•
 I²C standard MSB first byte format, ACK and NACK


**7.3.1.2 I²C Protocol**
**Protocol Features:**


•
 frame based communication
•
 7 bit device address


•
 upper 2 bits used as device group selector
•
 lower 5 bits used as device address


•
 1 to 31 bus slave devices and broadcast access


•
 8 bit device internal memory address space


Data words (10 bit words) are transferred in a compact byte manner. Data is always handled as 10 bit word values. If the bus 
master sends a number of data word stream bits which is not a multiple of 8, the additional fill bits at the end of the data 
stream will be ignored by the bus slave device.

**7.3.1.3.1 OTP user data protocol**


*Figure 7.3.1.3.1-1: OTP access protocol *


Packet structure to write user configuration into the OTP


Eight words (x10) of direct access memory (BUS_CONFIG :0x78 - 0x7F) area are used as protocol packets between host and 
the device.


For writes, 8 word packets are used. The OTP address is specified as:
Target Address = 
*PageNumber*
 x 128 + 
*Offset*
.


For an eight word I²C read/write frame with starting address 0x78, the packet details is mentioned below and shown in the 
figure above.


*The 
*PageNumber*
 is provided as data at address 0x7C
*The 
*Offset*
 as data at address 0x7D
*The 32 bit data is provided as :


Bits 31:24 at address 0x7B
Bits 23:16 at address 0x7A
Bits 15:08 at address 0x79
Bits 07:00 at address 0x78


*The data at address 0x7E indicates write/read:


0x00 indicates a read and 0x01 a write. For a read frame the data from 0x78-0x7B is ignored.


*For any communication to the device the data at address 0x7F has to be set to 0x01 , by the master. This is used for

*The 
*PageNumber*
 is provided as data at address 0x7C
*The 
*Offset*
 as data at address 0x7D
*The 32 bit data is provided as :


Bits 31:24 at address 0x7B
Bits 23:16 at address 0x7A
Bits 15:08 at address 0x79
Bits 07:00 at address 0x78


*The data at address 0x7E indicates write/read:


0x00 indicates a read and 0x01 a write. For a read frame the data from 0x78-0x7B is ignored.


*For any communication to the device the data at address 0x7F has to be set to 0x01 , by the master. This is used for


synchronization between I²C master and slave. The slave writes "0" to the address 0x7F on completion of the request. The 
master has to poll the data at address 0x7F to return to "0". Once the read data at address 0x7F is "0", next frame can be sent
to the device. 
**If this protocol is not followed, it may lead to unexpected behavior, inclusive of the device becoming unus-**
**able.**

Packet structure to load the OTP write algorithms in the device. For Start and Stop packets the data at address 0x78-0x7C are

For writing the user configuration data to the OTP memory area : The actual configuration data write has to be preceded and 
ended with special writes. Before writing to OTP area, OTP writing algorithms need to be loaded into RAM. The protocol 
packet for writing the OTP algorithms in the device is shown below.


An eight word write frame to load the write algorithms into the device consists of

* Address 0x79: Algorithm data bits 15:08

* Address 0x7B: Address offset for data bits 15:08
* Address 0x7C: "0x00"
* Address 0x7D: "0xFD" indicating OTP algorithm data
* Address 0x7E: "0x03" indicating special write command
* Address 0x7F: "0x01"

**7.3.1.3.3 OTP read/write steps**
Steps for writing user data to OTP:
The following list details the steps to program the user configuration data into the OTP.


1. Write the OTP write algorithms to the device
2. Force the PROG pin of the device to high
3. Read the I²C register 0x7F and wait until the data reads 0
4. Write 8 words starting from 0x78 (with REG = 0xFE) - Start of write cycle.
5. Read the I²C register 0x7F and wait until the data reads 0

6. Write I²C packet for OTP write, with Page no, offset and data words
7. For more writes, go to step 4
8. Write 8 words starting from 0x78 (with REG = 0xFF) - End of write cycle.
9. Force the PROG pin of the device to low


Steps for reading user data from OTP:
The following list details the steps to read the OTP.


1. Read the I²C register 0x7F and wait until it reads 0
2. Write 4 words starting from 0x7C with Page no, offset
3. Read the I²C register 0x7F and wait until it reads 0
4. Read 4 words starting from 0x78 for the data from the device


For data read from OTP the OTP write algorithm data need not be written. The OTP data can be read anytime.


The device monitors the OTP algorithm data being written into the RAM via the bus interface. In case of any error during this 
data transfer, a reset is generated on the NRESET pin. This NRESET pin should be monitored during OTP data transactions. In 
case a reset is observed while the OTP algorithm data is being written, the algorithm data transaction has to be repeated.


Example for OTP write using Elmos controller
(OTP write algorithms are already written and PROG=HIGH)
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C8 1 1F 78 00 00 00 00 00 FE 03 01 ; Start of write cycle
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C8 1 1F 78 01 02 03 04 6C 00 01 01 ; OTP address=0x00003600, data = 0x04030201
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C8 1 1F 78 05 06 07 08 6C 04 01 01 ; OTP address=0x00003604, data = 0x08070605
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C8 1 1F 78 09 0A 0B 0C 6C 08 01 01 ; OTP address=0x00003608, data = 0x0C0B0A09
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C8 1 1F 78 00 00 00 00 00 FF 03 01 ; End of write cycle


Example for OTP read using Elmos controller 
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
WI2C4 1 1F 7C 6C 00 00 01 ; OTP address=0x00003600
RI2C 1 1F 7F ; wait for return value of 0
RI2C4 1 1f 78 ; should return 01 02 03 04


**7.4 Input Interface**


The light functions are triggered using discrete pins. The input interface triggers the execution of sequences with different 
priority within the device. The device uses three fixed pins IN_0, IN_1 and ANI_IN and two optional pins for this function. The 
optional pins are multiplexed with LED channels and can be configured for input or as LED channel via LED_ALT_CONFIG 
register. All these pins can be configured for active high or active low polarity using IO_CONFIG register.


**7.4.1 Input Sampling**

**7.4 Input Interface**


The light functions are triggered using discrete pins. The input interface triggers the execution of sequences with different 
priority within the device. The device uses three fixed pins IN_0, IN_1 and ANI_IN and two optional pins for this function. The 
optional pins are multiplexed with LED channels and can be configured for input or as LED channel via LED_ALT_CONFIG 
register. All these pins can be configured for active high or active low polarity using IO_CONFIG register.

pins are executed within T
STEP
. For noise immunity the pins have voltage hysteresis and glitch filtering. The input sampling 
details are shown in the figure below.

*Figure 7.4.1-1: Input Sampling*


The inputs are sampled serially as shown in the figure, at every T
STEP
 interval. The digital pins (IN_0 and IN_1) are sampled first
followed by LED pins (IN_2_LED2, IN_3_LED3 and OE_LED10 ). In each sampling window an input is sampled thrice and the 
value which is at least twice in that interval is selected as the input value. Once detected in this manner , the input is not 
looked at till the next T
STEP
. The sampling of input and software filtering ensures that glitches in the signal are ignored. To 
ensure that an input signal is surely detected it has to be held active for at least T
STEP
 interval.


The internal T
STEP
 is asynchronous with respect to the external input signals. The serial sampling and lack of sync means that 
input signals triggered simultaneously can be detected with a delay of T
STEP
. This means that the input signal to sequence trig-
gering can have an uncertainty of T
STEP
 in addition to detection to trigger delay.


For a simultaneous excitation of triggers there can be a difference of T
STEP
 in the respective sequence getting triggered. To 
ensure consistent triggering of sequences follow the guidelines mentioned in the section: 7.6.1.3: Mode transition.


**7.4.2 OE PWM Masking**


The OE_LED10 pin, in case it is being used for the output enable functionality, can be used to mask PWM signals.
When the OE_LED10 pin is inactive (low level in case of non-inverted OE usage), the PWM pulses of all LED channels are sup-
pressed, which sets the related LED channel driver stages to an off state. When the OE_LED10 pin is active (high level in case 
of non-inverted OE usage), this mask is removed and PWM signals of LED channels are fed to the related LED driver stages.
The output enable signal does not block the internal sequence execution , only masks the application of the PWM signals to 
the LED channels.

**7.5 Digital IOs**


The signal polarity of ANI_IN, IN_0,IN_1,IN_2_LED2,IN_3_LED3,OE_LED10 pins can be configured using the IO_CONFIG value.
This allows to connect inverted control signals to the device.


The description in the following chapters refers to the internal signal states, which represent the "default" control signal 
polarity.


For LED pins configured as input pins ( IN_2_LED2, IN_3_LED3 and OE_LED10) there is pull-down current irrespective of the 
active high or active low polarity. These pins do not have a pull resistor, but have the current sink configured for minimum 
current.
ANI_IN, IN_0 and IN_1 show a pull-down behavior if active high polarity is selected. The pull direction changes with the selec-
ted polarity. It changes to pull-up if the active low polarity is selected.
The following figures show the pull-up and pull-down IO typical current behavior of the digital IOs. The internal pull resistor 
voltage will be limited to approximately V
DIG_PULL
+0.2V. For this reason the pull current saturates above V
DIG_PULL
+0.2V IO input 
voltage.

**7.6 User Sequence System**


The User sequence system sets the current and generates the PWM pulse signals needed to control the LED driver stages. 
The PWM duty cycle and current of each channel can be controlled using the instructions within a sequence.


**7.6.1 Sequences**


**7.6.1.1 Sequence Trigger & mode of operation**
The device offers up to eight sequences which are mapped to their corresponding input pins. At any point of time four 
sequences can run in parallel. The device offers two modes of operation Main mode and Animation mode.


•
 Main mode


This mode is meant for the basic light functions which implement the regulatory requirements i.e., TAIL, BRAKE, TURN.


•
 Animation mode


This mode is meant for non-critical light functions i.e LEAVE HOME, COME HOME.


The mode selection allows the device to have two times the number of light functions with one additional mode selection 
pin(ANI_IN). The only difference between the two modes is the priority. The Main mode has higher priority with respect to 
Animation mode. This is described in more detail in the Mode transition section.
The sequence mapping to the trigger signals, mode of operation and priority is shown in the table below.

**7.6.1.2 Sequence Configuration**
Each sequence can be configured to control any of the 16 LED channels.
The LED channels configured for alternate function , i.e. Diagnosis,Link,Input, and Output enable, will not be considered for 
binning and derating. In case a LED is shared between multiple sequences, in the event of parallel execution of the said 
sequences, the sequence having higher priority will drive the LED channel.
A sequence configuration consists of :
1. Sequence to channel association
2. A bit to enable/disable the sequence
3. Start & end address of the instructions which are to be run on sequence triggering.
4. Diagnostic channel association
5. A bit to select Single lamp/ Multi lamp (SLM/MLM) mode

**7.6.1.3 Mode Transition**
The modes are differentiated by the level of the ANI_IN signal. Active level of ANI_IN signal corresponds to animation mode 
and inactive level corresponds to main mode.


For transition from Main mode to Animation mode, the following conditions have to be satisfied
1. All active main mode sequences should be de-activated
2. The ANI_IN signal has to be active
3. There has to be at-least once TSTEP of quiet period (no Sequence triggered) between Animation mode activation and trig-
gering of animation mode sequence.


Transition from Animation mode to Main mode happens as soon as the ANI_IN signal is de-activated. The active animation 
sequences will be de-activated and corresponding Main mode sequences will be started.


To switch the device predictably between modes the recommended steps are


•
 For Main mode to animation mode transition


1. Deactivate all active triggers to ensure that none of the sequences are running.
2. 10ms after step 1, activate the ANI_IN signal to put the device in animation mode.
3. 10ms after step 2, any of the animation sequences can be triggered.
If any main mode sequence trigger is active when triggering the animation mode (step 2) , the device will continue to stay 
in main mode. The device will switch from main mode to animation mode only after all the active trigger signals have 
become inactive.

The fixed part of sequence database starts at 0x34B4 and can grow up to 0x36B3, depending on number of instructions. The 
variable part starts after the fixed part. The starting address of this variable part is placed at 0x34B0. The variable part of the 
sequence database can grow up to 0x3BF3, leaving the reserved spaces in between. ParIndex in the fixed part is 2 byte 
aligned. This variable part is used to store pwms (SETLNKxx) and pwm percentages (DIMx) for channels mentioned in the 
sequence (main or animation) to which this sequence database entry is associated with.


Example with 4 sequences and 11 database entries
Sequence Configuration


{1,X,X,X,X,0, 1, 0x00E0}, // Seq 0 - LED5, LED6 and LED7 ; start index = 0, stop index = 1
{1,X,X,X,X,2, 3, 0x1800}, // Seq 1 - LED11 and LED12 ; start index = 2, stop index = 3
{1,X,X,X,X,4, 5, 0x2000}, // Seq 2 - LED13 ; start index = 4, stop index = 5
{1,X,X,X,X,6,10, 0xC000}, // Seq 3 - LED14 and LED15 ; start index = 6, stop index = 10

**7.6.2.1 SETLNKON Instruction**
This instruction sets the LED channel to defined PWM and current values. The instruction effect is restricted to LED channels 
associated with this sequence. Other LED channels on the device will not be affected. The LED channel current is further 
modified by binning and derating. This command also turns the current source of the link channel, associated with this 
sequence, ON. The effect of the linking will be dependent on the pin configuration LED_ALT_CONFIG:LED_ALT_CONFIG. In 
case the channel is not configured for linking, the link operation will be ignored.

**7.6.2.4 DIM Instruction**
This instruction changes the PWM by user specified delta values and steps. The PWM value is saturated at 0% or 100% if 
reached within the defined time interval. The PWM of the channels is incremented/decremented from the previous PWM 
value for the channel. If the PWM values of the channels are not set by any command before this, the PWM's for the chan-
nels are assumed to be zero. On deactivation of the sequence, the history information is lost and the next activation would 
be a fresh cycle. The command also sets the current through the LED channels. The command effect is restricted to lighting 
LED's belonging to this sequence. The details of this instruction are shown in table below.


•
 During PWM duty cycle ramp up the device increments PWM pulse length to larger values and reloads these values a short


time after a previous PWM pulse has been finished. The PWM channels may get active "again" to "finish" the new (just 
loaded) PWM pulse length. This can result in the short pulses on the LED channel. This happens only during automatic 
internal duty cycle transition and does not happen for steady state conditions.

This instruction offers a higher change value as compared to the DIM command. This instruction changes the PWM by user

assumed to be zero. On deactivation of the sequence, the history information is lost and the next activation would be a fresh 
cycle. The PWM value is saturated at 0% or 100% if reached within the defined time interval. The command also sets the cur-
rent through the LED channels. The command effect is restricted to lighting LED's belonging to this sequence. The details of 
this instruction are shown in table below.

 During PWM duty cycle ramp up the device increments PWM pulse length to larger values and reloads these values a short


time after a previous PWM pulse has been finished. The PWM channels may get active "again" to "finish" the new (just 
loaded) PWM pulse length. This can result in the short pulses on the LED channel. This happens only during automatic 
internal duty cycle transition and does not happen for steady state conditions.

This instruction allows the code to restart from any point within the sequence. The jump address can be any number from 0
